thread.title: Appeal court REJECTS Donald Trump's emergency bid to restore his travel ban - Mirror Online
thread.title_full: Appeal court REJECTS Donald Trump's emergency bid to restore his travel ban - Mirror Online

author: Dan Bloom
title: Appeal court REJECTS Donald Trump's emergency bid to restore his travel ban - Mirror Online
text:
News Appeal court REJECTS Donald Trump's emergency bid to restore his travel ban The furious President had appealed against a federal judge's "ridiculous" order lifting his ban on refugees and people from seven Muslim nations Share The President looking surly-faced with First Lady Melania at the 60th Annual Red Cross Gala at his Florida resort (Photo: REUTERS) Share Get politics updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
An appeal court has rejected Donald Trump's emergency bid to restore his controversial travel ban. 
The furious President had appealed against a federal judge's "ridiculous" order lifting his ban on refugees and people from seven Muslim nations. 
But hours later an appeal court said it would not reinstate the travel ban until the case had been heard fully - meaning the row will go on for days. 
In a late-night ruling, the 9th US Circuit Court of Appeals in San Francisco denied the President's "request for an immediate administrative stay pending full consideration of the emergency motion." Read More 
It gave the states of Washington and Minnesota, which opposed the travel ban, until 8am GMT on Monday to file their fresh objections. The White House must wait until Monday evening at the very earliest (Photo: REUTERS) The President did manage one or two smiles last night - but hit out viciously on Twitter (Photo: REUTERS) 
The White House will then have until 11pm GMT on Monday to file its arguments in support of reinstating the ban. 
Trump's radical policy bans all refugees for 120 days, Syrian refugees indefinitely, and citizens from seven Muslim-majority countries - Syria, Iraq, Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan and Yemen - for 90 days. 
Last night the furious president slammed James Robart, the "so-called" judge who lifted the travel ban , as the Department of Justice filed its appeal. 
The judge appointed by former Republican President George W. Bush questioned the constitutionality of Trump's order. 
But Trump ranted on Twitter: "The opinion of this so-called judge, which essentially takes law-enforcement away from our country, is ridiculous and will be overturned!" 
Acting Solicitor General Noel Francisco claimed the president's power was "largely immune from judicial control" when it comes to immigration. 
The President later told reporters at his private Mar-a-Lago resort in Palm Beach, Florida: "We'll win. For the safety of the country, we'll win." Read More
